Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Distributed Network of BacteriaBots

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project exploits the sophisticated and robust machinery of bacteria for actuation, sensing, communication, and control of a new class of micron scale robotic systems called BacteriaBots. This is achieved through (1) computational modeling of bio-actuation and sensing, (2) use of quorum sensing-based behaviors, and (3) use of mobile networks of BacteriaBots.

This effort contributes to the critical understanding required to advance the science of bio-hybrid micro-robotics and distributed control at reduced length scales. This holds enormous promise for socio-economic benefit by significantly impacting the fields of bio-sensing, medicine, micro-manufacturing and assembly, microelectronics, and bio-materials. A multi-tier education and outreach plan integrates research elements and discoveries into multi-disciplinary educational research experiences for K-12, undergraduate and graduate students.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
Control and communication for a distributed network of robotic agents is a challenging problem to solve at the microscale. In nature, bacteria utilize chemical signaling to execute controlled movement, communication, and collaborative task completion. Chemotactic response (i.e. biased random walk of bacteria towards a chemo-attractant source) enables effective sensing and creates a biased distribution of bacteria in a field. Quorum sensing allows a robust collective response to be achieved at specific bacteria number densities. In this project, we developed the scientific knowledge and the technology needed in order to exploit the sophisticated and robust machinery of bacteria for actuation, sensing, communication, and control of a new class of micron scale (characteristic length: 2-10 μm) robotic systems called “BacteriaBots”. A BacteriaBot is a bio-hybrid swimming microrobot realized by interfacing an ensemble of live engineered bacteria with a microfabricated robot body (Fig. 1). Mobile Networks of BacteriaBots (MNBB) can be utilized as intelligent, reconfigurable and adaptable networks to address challenges in sensing, additive manufacturing, and transport and delivery of cargo at reduced length scales. In contrast to other microrobotic systems, BacteriaBots have unique advantages, such as the ability to harness chemical energy from the environment for power and most importantly the potential to be employed in large numbers as inexpensive agents of distributed systems to conquer goals only possible through teamwork. Therefore, MNBBs are envisioned to impact a diverse range of fields, including minimally invasive diagnosis, localized drug delivery, environmental monitoring, and homeland security.

 

Intellectual Merit: Development of bio-hybrid microrobotic systems is a promising approach towards the attainment of “smart interfaces” where bacteria or cells are used as controllers for non-living systems. Programming the biotic component of the MNBB (i.e. bacteria) to interrogate the environment for multiple stimuli of interest, process it and then convey a set of outputs to control the BacteriaBots both at the single agent and population scale, will offer novel smart interfaces for autonomous control. The transformative nature of this proposal is in utilization of bacterial quorum sensing principles towards enabling the first generation of a distributed network of mobile robots less than 10 microns in size.

 

Broader Impacts: This effort contributed to the critical understanding required to advance the science of bio-hybrid microrobotics and distributed control at reduced lengthscales and developed enabling means towards achieving real-life objectives through distributed control of MNBBs. This next generation distributed robotic systems hold promise to have enormous socioeconomic benefits and significantly impact many fields-including biosensing, medicine, and additive manufacturing. We also established a multi-tier education and outreach plan that integrated research elements and discoveries into multidisciplinary educational and research experiences for K-12, undergraduate and graduate students.

 

Major outcomes: Nature has perfected cells to survive and efficiently perform specific functions such as sensing, motility, self-healing, transportation and communication. The challenge we as engineers face is to harness these functions and adaptability to our needs. This project focused on developing a first of its kind distributed network of bacteria-based mobile biorobots less than 10 microns in size. The major outcomes of this NSF-supported effort are:

  • Computationally modeled bio-actuation and bio-sensing of each BacteriaBot agent to advance understanding of their stochastic behavior and utilized the finding to design more effective and efficient BacteriaBot agents. Theoretical findings were combined with microfabrication techniques to fabricate optimized BacteriaBots. A library of bacteria-assisted delivery systems was developed by coupling live engineered bacteria with particles of various geometries and the transport of such synthetic bacteria-based systems was investigated in absence and presence of chemical cues using microfluidic platforms (Fig. 2).

 

  • Utilized synthetic biology to engineer quorum sensing (i.e. cell density-dependent regulation of target genes) regulated green fluorescent protein (GFP) expression in bacteria and achieve robust and predictable communication in a network of BacteriaBots. Computational modeling and microfluidic assay devices were utilized to study and characterize the coordinated behavior of bacteria. We quantitatively and accurately captured their emergent behavior with respect to both chemotaxis and quorum sensing, allowing us to use the model predictively to design synthetic genetic components.

 

  • Realizing a prototypical MNBB for chemotaxis based biosensing that uses quorum sensing to communicate when a chemical of interest is sensed and broadcasts the detection. The computational and experimental platforms developed in this effort was utilized to develop precisely engineered BacteriaBots that express GFP.

The work completed herein serves as a transformative stepping stone towards the development of an autonomous network of bacteria-based bio-hybrid systems with enhanced transport properties and capable of executing pre-programmed multi-agent coordinated tasks (for example drug delivery) upon their arrival at the target site.  

 


Last Modified: 02/09/2017
Modified by: Bahareh Behkam

    BacteriaBot Schematic
  • Spherical and elliptical-shaped BacteriaBots both effectively response to chemical gradients in their environment irrespective of their geometry
    Ali Sahari and Aziz Traore, MicroN BASE Laboratory, Virginia Tech
    Copyrighted
    Bahareh Behkam
    BacteriaBot Chemotaxis Response
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Control and communication for a distributed network of robotic agents is a challenging problem to solve at the microscale. In nature, bacteria utilize chemical signaling to execute controlled movement, communication, and collaborative task completion. Chemotactic response (i.e. biased random walk of bacteria towards a chemo-attractant source) enables effective sensing and creates a biased distribution of bacteria in a field. Quorum sensing allows a robust collective response to be achieved at specific bacteria number densities. In this project, we developed the scientific knowledge and the technology needed in order to exploit the sophisticated and robust machinery of bacteria for actuation, sensing, communication, and control of a new class of micron scale (characteristic length: 2-10 μm) robotic systems called "BacteriaBots". A BacteriaBot is a bio-hybrid swimming microrobot realized by interfacing an ensemble of live engineered bacteria with a microfabricated robot body (Fig. 1). Mobile Networks of BacteriaBots (MNBB) can be utilized as intelligent, reconfigurable and adaptable networks to address challenges in sensing, additive manufacturing, and transport and delivery of cargo at reduced length scales. In contrast to other microrobotic systems, BacteriaBots have unique advantages, such as the ability to harness chemical energy from the environment for power and most importantly the potential to be employed in large numbers as inexpensive agents of distributed systems to conquer goals only possible through teamwork. Therefore, MNBBs are envisioned to impact a diverse range of fields, including minimally invasive diagnosis, localized drug delivery, environmental monitoring, and homeland security. Intellectual Merit: Development of bio-hybrid microrobotic systems is a promising approach towards the attainment of "smart interfaces" where bacteria or cells are used as controllers for non-living systems. Programming the biotic component of the MNBB (i.e. bacteria) to interrogate the environment for multiple stimuli of interest, process it and then convey a set of outputs to control the BacteriaBots both at the single agent and population scale, will offer novel smart interfaces for autonomous control. The transformative nature of this proposal is in utilization of bacterial quorum sensing principles towards enabling the first generation of a distributed network of mobile robots less than 10 microns in size. Broader Impacts: This effort contributed to the critical understanding required to advance the science of bio-hybrid microrobotics and distributed control at reduced lengthscales and developed enabling means towards achieving real-life objectives through distributed control of MNBBs. This next generation distributed robotic systems hold promise to have enormous socioeconomic benefits and significantly impact many fields-including biosensing, medicine, and additive manufacturing. We also established a multi-tier education and outreach plan that integrated research elements and discoveries into multidisciplinary educational and research experiences for K-12, undergraduate and graduate students. Major outcomes: Nature has perfected cells to survive and efficiently perform specific functions such as sensing, motility, self-healing, transportation and communication. The challenge we as engineers face is to harness these functions and adaptability to our needs. This project focused on developing a first of its kind distributed network of bacteria-based mobile biorobots less than 10 microns in size. The major outcomes of this NSF-supported effort are: Computationally modeled bio-actuation and bio-sensing of each BacteriaBot agent to advance understanding of their stochastic behavior and utilized the finding to design more effective and efficient BacteriaBot agents. Theoretical findings were combined with microfabrication techniques to fabricate optimized BacteriaBots. A library of bacteria-assisted delivery systems was developed by coupling live engineered bacteria with particles of various geometries and the transport of such synthetic bacteria-based systems was investigated in absence and presence of chemical cues using microfluidic platforms (Fig. 2). Utilized synthetic biology to engineer quorum sensing (i.e. cell density-dependent regulation of target genes) regulated green fluorescent protein (GFP) expression in bacteria and achieve robust and predictable communication in a network of BacteriaBots. Computational modeling and microfluidic assay devices were utilized to study and characterize the coordinated behavior of bacteria. We quantitatively and accurately captured their emergent behavior with respect to both chemotaxis and quorum sensing, allowing us to use the model predictively to design synthetic genetic components. Realizing a prototypical MNBB for chemotaxis based biosensing that uses quorum sensing to communicate when a chemical of interest is sensed and broadcasts the detection. The computational and experimental platforms developed in this effort was utilized to develop precisely engineered BacteriaBots that express GFP. The work completed herein serves as a transformative stepping stone towards the development of an autonomous network of bacteria-based bio-hybrid systems with enhanced transport properties and capable of executing pre-programmed multi-agent coordinated tasks (for example drug delivery) upon their arrival at the target site.
